abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Irrigation Development
            Project (IDP) for Armenia were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development moderate, Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            also satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the IDP
            experience with the irrigation and drainage (I&D) sector
            in Armenia shows that deep reforms work well when there is
            strong commitment to reform overtime. As was in the case of
            Mexico, IDP successfully used financing of rehabilitation
            works as a bargaining tool to promote transfers that were
            not very economically attractive to users given the
            dilapidated state of the systems and the chronic lack of
            funds for operation and maintenance (O&M). Institutional
            arrangements giving more responsibility and say to farmers,
            engage the energy of the private sector, and reduce
            governments role. Emphasis on decentralization, financial
            viability and accountability of water services providers,
            empowerment through rights and responsibilities of water
            users and their organizations, always result in higher
            impact of I&D rehabilitation investments, sustainable
            transformations and dynamism. Stakeholders active
            participation in the I&D investments and sector reform
            processes, and building capacity (organizational and
            managerial skills, and databases) in agricultural water
            projects has demonstrated, once again, that it derives in
            more satisfactory results. Where market absorption exists,
            expansion and productivity increases through improvements of
            agricultural water management can strongly contribute to
            poverty alleviation in rural areas, were most poor live.
